Note: MDCN8000 (6 UOC) is a multi-term course run over 3-terms for a total UOC of 18. MDCN8000 is only available to students undertaking our Course Work intensive Honours program (18 UOC from research and 30 UOC from Coursework). 


The learning and teaching philosophy underpinning this course is centred on BSc (Med) Hons students taking on the role of researcher. In doing so, they develop advanced disciplinary knowledge, the use of specialised techniques/methodology relevant to their chosen research area, critical thinking, evaluation and synthesis of information, in addition to scientific research communication in the oral and written forms.


The principal form of teaching is based on research supervision and direction by specialist researchers within UNSW Medicine. Complementary to this, online Research Skills modules will be delivered and have been designed to provide training to BSc (Med) Hons students in diverse areas that constitute research practice. Learning outcomes from this course will form the basis for future pursuits in medical research and transferrable skills.


The information for this course is in the form of experimental techniques, protocols, technical tips and materials, which are usually provided by each research environment and supervisor. In addition, self-directed use of other resources such as web-based sources are expected. You will need to maintain consistent communication with your supervisor and actively seek assistance from your supervisor or co-supervisor to clarify your understanding, as required.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e4276835dbe2e810be4672f5f39619b9","name":"Independent research - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Project Manuscript","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"75","description":"

Assessment Descriptioin: The format of the Project Manuscript is to comply with the guidelines set out in the BSc (Med) Hons Project Manuscript - Instructions to Authors and should contain: 1) Title Page, 2) Abstract, 3) Statement of Contribution, 4) Acknowledgments, 5) Introduction with hypotheses and aims (or research questions), 6) Methodology, 7) Results, 8) Discussion, 9) References, 10) Reflection and 11) Appendix (if appropriate).

The minimum word count is 4000 and a maximum is 5000 words for the project manuscript (excluding the reflection). This word limit excludes the abstract, statement of contribution, acknowledgements and reference section, as well as the appendix (if present), tables, figures, boxes (for qualitative data only), figure legends, in-text citations.

The abstract should succinctly and accurately summarise the aims and outcomes of the project (maximum 250 words). The statement of contribution should clearly declare the specific components of the research that were undertaken independently by the student, and those components of the research that were done in collaboration with others, or that were performed by others. Being trained or supervised in a technique, but then generating the data independently, or being given advice or feedback from a supervisor or colleague, does not need to be described in this statement of contribution (but could be listed in acknowledgements). The acknowledgments should recognise the contributions (reagents, training, advice, feedback, support etc.) of others to the project.

The brief introduction aims, and hypothesis section should define the problem being examined and place it in the context of published work in the area without being a complete review of the literature. It should identify the limitations of the literature and areas of controversy and give clear and valid aims and hypotheses or research questions. The methodology should be appropriate and valid for the stated aims (or research questions) and be clearly described and fully referenced. The results should reflect a significant body of work including enough controls and replicates and analysis of data using appropriate statistical tests. Material needed for a complete understanding or evaluation of the work, but which does not fit well in the Project Manuscript format, should be included as supplementary data. Presentation of the results should be clear and logical and should use figures, tables, etc. The discussion should be relevant to the introduction, methodology, and results sections, logical in presentation and scientific content, show critical/creative analysis, place the findings of the study in the context of past studies.

The reflection section of the Project Manuscript needs to propose a future project based on the findings obtained during the BSc (Med) Hons year. The research proposal needs to provide a short rationale, hypotheses and aims (or research questions), a brief outline of methodology, potential outcomes and what they would mean to the body of literature with an emphasis on improving Indigenous health outcomes. A maximum of 1000 words will be required for this section.  

Please note that all work which is integral to the Project Manuscript but was not performed by the BSc (Med) Hons student (i.e. was undertaken by another member of the supervisor's and/or co-supervisor's research group) is to be clearly disclosed in the Methodology Results and/or appendix sections, where appropriate. This work may then be referred to in the Discussion and be assessed in the context of the work undertaken by the BSc (Med) Hons student.

Feedback Process:  Students will receive feedback by an examiner(s) that have been assigned to assess the literature review based on clear marking criteria. Students are also encourage to discuss the feedback with their supervisors. Students are not ranked or compared to each other when determining the assessment of their performance. The students will be encouraged to use the feedback when preparing for the Final Report that will use similar marking criteria.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2027a835dbe2e810be4672f5f396195c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2427a835dbe2e810be4672f5f396195d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2427a835dbe2e810be4672f5f396195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"2c27a835dbe2e810be4672f5f396195c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2c27a835dbe2e810be4672f5f396195d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2c27a835dbe2e810be4672f5f396195e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b427a835dbe2e810be4672f5f3961964","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Research Performance ","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

Assessment Description:  Supervisors will grade the student's performance twice during BSc (Med) Hons (Term 3) by awarding a mark out of 100. This mark will contribute 10% of the student's overall BSc (Med) Hons mark. In addition to awarding a mark, supervisors are expected to make comments and provide feedback to the student about their progress during this performance review.

Supervisors may comment on such topics as the student's participation in the collegial activities of the Research Group/Department/School (if appropriate), attendance, and the ability to meet deadlines. Space will be provided for the supervisor to add comments, or flag concerns relating to the student's progress. These comments will be released to students.

Both students and supervisors are encouraged to discuss all concerns as they arise. Where concerns arise that cannot be resolved between the student and supervisor, or where either party wishes additional advice, both parties are encouraged to contact the BSc (Med) Hons coordinator as soon as possible.

In all cases the initial approach is confidential and may not need to go further. However, where the BSc (Med) Hons convenor feels further action is warranted the BSc (Med) Hons convenor may approach the supervisor and/or student, or seek guidance from the BSc (Med) Hons Committee and/or UNSW bodies. All concerns will be dealt with in accordance with the UNSW policy on grievance resolution procedure for undergraduate and postgraduate (coursework) students.

Feedback Process:  Students will be provided feedback directly from their supervisor using clear criteria.

Assessment Description: The presentation should largely cover the results of the research project. A clear, concise and appropriate introduction should be provided which identifies the limitations of the literature and areas of controversy. Clear and valid aims and hypotheses or research questions should be stated. The results should reflect a significant body of work including sufficient controls and replicates and analysis of data using appropriate statistical tests. The specific contribution of the student to the results, should be included as a single Statement of Contribution slide (see description of "Statement of Contribution"; under Project Manuscript and in the "Instructions to Authors" section). Presentation of the results should be clear and logical and should use figures, tables, etc. The significance of any important findings should be addressed, and appropriate conclusions made. The results of the study should be placed within a broader context and suggestions should be made for future experiments. The seminar should have clear and logical flow, good pace (i.e. neither hurried nor laboured) and use good visual quality slides and/or overheads. The student should demonstrate understanding of the questions raised during question time by giving appropriate answers and where appropriate based on the literature and current findings from their project.

A 250-word abstract will be required approximately 1 week before the Final Seminar.

Feedback Process: Students will receive feedback by an examiner(s) that have been assigned to assess the Introductory Seminar; based on clear marking criteria. Students are also encourage to discuss the feedback with their supervisors. Students are not ranked or compared to each other when determining the assessment of their performance.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MDCN8001 - Medicine Honours","description":"

 


The learning and teaching philosophy underpinning this course is centred on BSc (Med) Hons students taking on the role of researcher. In doing so, they develop advanced disciplinary knowledge, the use of specialised techniques/methodology relevant to their chosen research area, critical thinking, evaluation and synthesis of information, in addition to scientific research communication in the oral and written forms.


The principal form of teaching is based on research supervision and direction by specialist researchers within UNSW Medicine. Complementary to this, online Research Skills modules will be delivered and have been designed to provide training to BSc (Med) Hons students in diverse areas that constitute research practice. Learning outcomes from this course will form the basis for future pursuits in medical research and transferrable skills.


The information for this course is in the form of experimental techniques, protocols, technical tips and materials, which are usually provided by each research environment and supervisor. In addition, self-directed use of other resources such as web-based sources are expected. You will need to maintain consistent communication with your supervisor and actively seek assistance from your supervisor or co-supervisor to clarify your understanding, as required.

Assessment Description: The presentation should largely cover the results of the research project. A clear, concise and appropriate introduction should be provided which identifies the limitations of the literature and areas of controversy. Clear and valid aims and hypotheses or research questions should be stated. The results should reflect a significant body of work including sufficient controls and replicates and analysis of data using appropriate statistical tests. The specific contribution of the student to the results, should be included as a single Statement of Contribution slide (see description of "Statement of Contribution"; under Project Manuscript and in the "Instructions to Authors" section). Presentation of the results should be clear and logical and should use figures, tables, etc. The significance of any important findings should be addressed, and appropriate conclusions made. The results of the study should be placed within a broader context and suggestions should be made for future experiments. The seminar should have clear and logical flow, good pace (i.e. neither hurried nor laboured) and use good visual quality slides and/or overheads. The student should demonstrate understanding of the questions raised during question time by giving appropriate answers and where appropriate based on the literature and current findings from their project.

A 250-word abstract will be required approximately 1 week before the Final Seminar.

Feedback Process: Students will receive feedback by an examiner(s) that have been assigned to assess the Introductory Seminar; based on clear marking criteria. Students are also encourage to discuss the feedback with their supervisors. Students are not ranked or compared to each other when determining the assessment of thier performance.

Assessment Description:  Supervisors will grade the student's performance twice during BSc (Med) Hons (Term 1 and Term 3) by awarding a mark out of 100. This mark (5% for each research performance report) will contribute 10% of the student's overall BSc (Med) Hons mark. In addition to awarding a mark, supervisors are expected to make comments and provide feedback to the student about their progress during this performance review.

Supervisors may comment on such topics as the student's participation in the collegial activities of the Research Group/Department/School (if appropriate), attendance, and the ability to meet deadlines. Space will be provided for the supervisor to add comments, or flag concerns relating to the student's progress. These comments will be released to students.

Both students and supervisors are encouraged to discuss all concerns as they arise. Where concerns arise that cannot be resolved between the student and supervisor, or where either party wishes additional advice, both parties are encouraged to contact the BSc (Med) Hons coordinator as soon as possible.

In all cases the initial approach is confidential and may not need to go further. However, where the BSc (Med) Hons convenor feels further action is warranted the BSc (Med) Hons convenor may approach the supervisor and/or student, or seek guidance from the BSc (Med) Hons Committee and/or UNSW bodies. All concerns will be dealt with in accordance with the UNSW policy on grievance resolution procedure for undergraduate and postgraduate (coursework) students.

Feedback Process:  Students will be provided feedback directly from their supervisor using clear criteria.

Assessment Descriptioin: The format of the Project Manuscript is to comply with the guidelines set out in the BSc (Med) Hons Project Manuscript - Instructions to Authors and should contain: 1) Title Page, 2) Abstract, 3) Statement of Contribution, 4) Acknowledgments, 5) Introduction with hypotheses and aims (or research questions), 6) Methodology, 7) Results, 8) Discussion, 9) References, 10) Reflection and 11) Appendix (if appropriate).

The minimum word count is 4000 and a maximum is 5000 words for the project manuscript (excluding the reflection). This word limit excludes the abstract, statement of contribution, acknowledgements and reference section, as well as the appendix (if present), tables, figures, boxes (for qualitative data only), figure legends, in-text citations.

The abstract should succinctly and accurately summarise the aims and outcomes of the project (maximum 250 words). The statement of contribution should clearly declare the specific components of the research that were undertaken independently by the student, and those components of the research that were done in collaboration with others, or that were performed by others. Being trained or supervised in a technique, but then generating the data independently, or being given advice or feedback from a supervisor or colleague, does not need to be described in this statement of contribution (but could be listed in acknowledgements). The acknowledgments should recognise the contributions (reagents, training, advice, feedback, support etc.) of others to the project.

The brief introduction aims, and hypothesis section should define the problem being examined and place it in the context of published work in the area without being a complete review of the literature. It should identify the limitations of the literature and areas of controversy and give clear and valid aims and hypotheses or research questions. The methodology should be appropriate and valid for the stated aims (or research questions) and be clearly described and fully referenced. The results should reflect a significant body of work including enough controls and replicates and analysis of data using appropriate statistical tests. Material needed for a complete understanding or evaluation of the work, but which does not fit well in the Project Manuscript format, should be included as supplementary data. Presentation of the results should be clear and logical and should use figures, tables, etc. The discussion should be relevant to the introduction, methodology, and results sections, logical in presentation and scientific content, show critical/creative analysis, place the findings of the study in the context of past studies.

The reflection section of the Project Manuscript needs to propose a future project based on the findings obtained during the BSc (Med) Hons year. The research proposal needs to provide a short rationale, hypotheses and aims (or research questions), a brief outline of methodology, potential outcomes and what they would mean to the body of literature with an emphasis on improving Indigenous health outcomes. A maximum of 1000 words will be required for this section.  

Please note that all work which is integral to the Project Manuscript but was not performed by the BSc (Med) Hons student (i.e. was undertaken by another member of the supervisor's and/or co-supervisor's research group) is to be clearly disclosed in the Methodology Results and/or appendix sections, where appropriate. This work may then be referred to in the Discussion and be assessed in the context of the work undertaken by the BSc (Med) Hons student.

Feedback Process:  Students will receive feedback by an examiner(s) that have been assigned to assess the literature reveiw based on clear marking criteria. Students are also encourage to discuss the feedback with their supervisors. Students are not ranked or compared to each other when determining the assessment of thier performance. The students will be encouraged to use the feedback when preparing for the Final Report that will use similar marking criteria.

Assessment Description: The Literature Review is 3,000 words (+/- 10%) and as the name implies, should give a detailed account of published scientific investigations which are relevant to the project being undertaken. It should contain the following sections: 1) Introduction, 2) Hypothesis and Aims or Research Questions, 3) Methodology (study design) and 4) Reference List.

The introduction should identify the limitations of the literature and/or areas of controversy and assess them critically. It should cite appropriate studies in the field and have clear and logical flow. After introducing the research area/background, the section comprising aims, hypotheses or research questions and methodology is an opportunity to clearly state the research question to be addressed and how this will be achieved. The stated aims should relate to the area(s) outlined in the introduction and the hypotheses should be clear and valid. Together sections 2 and 3 should contain a maximum of 450-500 words (i.e. approximately 15% of the Literature Review).

Methodology are to be summarised clearly and concisely and be appropriate and valid for the stated aim(s). Absolutely no results are to be included in the Literature Review. The word count for the Literature Review excludes diagrams, tables, figures, in-text citation, final reference list, which should be integrated into the appropriate sections of the text.

Feedback Process: Students will receive feedback by an examiner(s) that have been assigned to assess the literature reveiw based on clear marking criteria. Students are also encourage to discuss the feedback with their supervisors. Students are not ranked or compared to each other when determining the assessment of thier performance. The students will be encouraged to use the feedback when preparing for the Final Report that will use similar marking criteria.

contentlets.description:
The learning and teaching philosophy underpinning this course is centred on BSc (Med) Hons students taking on the role of researcher. In doing so, they develop advanced disciplinary knowledge, the use of specialised techniques/methodology relevant to their chosen research area, critical thinking, evaluation and synthesis of information, in addition to scientific research communication in the oral and written forms.

The principal form of teaching is based on research supervision and direction by specialist researchers within UNSW Medicine. Complementary to this, online Research Skills modules will be delivered and have been designed to provide training to BSc (Med) Hons students in diverse areas that constitute research practice. Learning outcomes from this course will form the basis for future pursuits in medical research and transferrable skills.

The information for this course is in the form of experimental techniques, protocols, technical tips and materials, which are usually provided by each research environment and supervisor. In addition, self-directed use of other resources such as web-based sources are expected. You will need to maintain consistent communication with your supervisor and actively seek assistance from your supervisor or co-supervisor to clarify your understanding, as required.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3381876c1b52a410d5fb0fabdc4bcbe2","name":"Independent research - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Manuscript","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Assessment Descriptioin: The format of the Project Manuscript is to comply with the guidelines set out in the BSc (Med) Hons Project Manuscript - Instructions to Authors and should contain: 1) Title Page, 2) Abstract, 3) Statement of Contribution, 4) Acknowledgments, 5) Introduction with hypotheses and aims (or research questions), 6) Methodology, 7) Results, 8) Discussion, 9) References, 10) Reflection and 11) Appendix (if appropriate).

The minimum word count is 4000 and a maximum is 5000 words for the project manuscript (excluding the reflection). This word limit excludes the abstract, statement of contribution, acknowledgements and reference section, as well as the appendix (if present), tables, figures, boxes (for qualitative data only), figure legends, in-text citations.

The abstract should succinctly and accurately summarise the aims and outcomes of the project (maximum 250 words). The statement of contribution should clearly declare the specific components of the research that were undertaken independently by the student, and those components of the research that were done in collaboration with others, or that were performed by others. Being trained or supervised in a technique, but then generating the data independently, or being given advice or feedback from a supervisor or colleague, does not need to be described in this statement of contribution (but could be listed in acknowledgements). The acknowledgments should recognise the contributions (reagents, training, advice, feedback, support etc.) of others to the project.

The brief introduction aims, and hypothesis section should define the problem being examined and place it in the context of published work in the area without being a complete review of the literature. It should identify the limitations of the literature and areas of controversy and give clear and valid aims and hypotheses or research questions. The methodology should be appropriate and valid for the stated aims (or research questions) and be clearly described and fully referenced. The results should reflect a significant body of work including enough controls and replicates and analysis of data using appropriate statistical tests. Material needed for a complete understanding or evaluation of the work, but which does not fit well in the Project Manuscript format, should be included as supplementary data. Presentation of the results should be clear and logical and should use figures, tables, etc. The discussion should be relevant to the introduction, methodology, and results sections, logical in presentation and scientific content, show critical/creative analysis, place the findings of the study in the context of past studies.

The reflection section of the Project Manuscript needs to propose a future project based on the findings obtained during the BSc (Med) Hons year. The research proposal needs to provide a short rationale, hypotheses and aims (or research questions), a brief outline of methodology, potential outcomes and what they would mean to the body of literature with an emphasis on improving Indigenous health outcomes. A maximum of 1000 words will be required for this section.  

Please note that all work which is integral to the Project Manuscript but was not performed by the BSc (Med) Hons student (i.e. was undertaken by another member of the supervisor's and/or co-supervisor's research group) is to be clearly disclosed in the Methodology Results and/or appendix sections, where appropriate. This work may then be referred to in the Discussion and be assessed in the context of the work undertaken by the BSc (Med) Hons student.

Feedback Process:  Students will receive feedback by an examiner(s) that have been assigned to assess the literature reveiw based on clear marking criteria. Students are also encourage to discuss the feedback with their supervisors. Students are not ranked or compared to each other when determining the assessment of thier performance. The students will be encouraged to use the feedback when preparing for the Final Report that will use similar marking criteria.

Assessment Description:  Supervisors will grade the student's performance twice during BSc (Med) Hons (Term 1 and Term 3) by awarding a mark out of 100. This mark (5% for each research performance report) will contribute 10% of the student's overall BSc (Med) Hons mark. In addition to awarding a mark, supervisors are expected to make comments and provide feedback to the student about their progress during this performance review.

Supervisors may comment on such topics as the student's participation in the collegial activities of the Research Group/Department/School (if appropriate), attendance, and the ability to meet deadlines. Space will be provided for the supervisor to add comments, or flag concerns relating to the student's progress. These comments will be released to students.

Both students and supervisors are encouraged to discuss all concerns as they arise. Where concerns arise that cannot be resolved between the student and supervisor, or where either party wishes additional advice, both parties are encouraged to contact the BSc (Med) Hons coordinator as soon as possible.

In all cases the initial approach is confidential and may not need to go further. However, where the BSc (Med) Hons convenor feels further action is warranted the BSc (Med) Hons convenor may approach the supervisor and/or student, or seek guidance from the BSc (Med) Hons Committee and/or UNSW bodies. All concerns will be dealt with in accordance with the UNSW policy on grievance resolution procedure for undergraduate and postgraduate (coursework) students.

Feedback Process:  Students will be provided feedback directly from their supervisor using clear criteria.

Assessment Description: The presentation should largely cover the results of the research project. A clear, concise and appropriate introduction should be provided which identifies the limitations of the literature and areas of controversy. Clear and valid aims and hypotheses or research questions should be stated. The results should reflect a significant body of work including sufficient controls and replicates and analysis of data using appropriate statistical tests. The specific contribution of the student to the results, should be included as a single Statement of Contribution slide (see description of "Statement of Contribution"; under Project Manuscript and in the "Instructions to Authors" section). Presentation of the results should be clear and logical and should use figures, tables, etc. The significance of any important findings should be addressed, and appropriate conclusions made. The results of the study should be placed within a broader context and suggestions should be made for future experiments. The seminar should have clear and logical flow, good pace (i.e. neither hurried nor laboured) and use good visual quality slides and/or overheads. The student should demonstrate understanding of the questions raised during question time by giving appropriate answers and where appropriate based on the literature and current findings from their project.

A 250-word abstract will be required approximately 1 week before the Final Seminar.

Feedback Process: Students will receive feedback by an examiner(s) that have been assigned to assess the Introductory Seminar; based on clear marking criteria. Students are also encourage to discuss the feedback with their supervisors. Students are not ranked or compared to each other when determining the assessment of thier performance.

contentlets.description:
The learning and teaching philosophy underpinning this course is centred on BSc (Med) Hons students taking on the role of researcher. In doing so, they develop advanced disciplinary knowledge, the use of specialised techniques/methodology relevant to their chosen research area, critical thinking, evaluation and synthesis of information, in addition to scientific research communication in the oral and written forms.

The principal form of teaching is based on research supervision and direction by specialist researchers within UNSW Medicine. Complementary to this, online Research Skills modules will be delivered and have been designed to provide training to BSc (Med) Hons students in diverse areas that constitute research practice. Learning outcomes from this course will form the basis for future pursuits in medical research and transferrable skills.

The information for this course is in the form of experimental techniques, protocols, technical tips and materials, which are usually provided by each laboratory and supervisor. In addition, self-directed use of other resources such as web-based sources are expected. You will need to maintain consistent communication with your supervisor and actively seek assistance from your supervisor or co-supervisor to clarify your understanding, as required.

The learning and teaching philosophy underpinning this course is centred on BSc (Med) Hons students taking on the role of researcher. Complementary to this, online Research Skills modules will be delivered and have been designed to provide training to BSc (Med) Hons students in diverse areas that constitute research practice. Learning outcomes from this course will form the basis for future pursuits in medical research and transferrable skills.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2c8ab3fcdbabac10fe4b322af49619b3","name":"Independent research - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Research Performance","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

DESCRIPTION

Supervisor(s) will grade the student’s performance during Honours (Term 3) by awarding a mark based on a rubric. This mark will contribute 10% of the student’s overall Honours mark. In addition to awarding a mark, supervisors are expected to make comments and provide feedback to the student about their progress during this performance review.

Supervisors may comment on such topics as the student’s participation in the collegial activities of the Research Group/Department/School (if appropriate), attendance, and the ability to meet deadlines. Space will be provided for the supervisor to add comments, or flag concerns relating to the student’s progress. These comments will be released to students.

Both students and supervisors are encouraged to discuss all concerns as they arise. Where concerns arise that cannot be resolved between the student and supervisor, or where either party wishes additional advice, both parties are encouraged to contact the ILP coordinator as soon as possible.

In all cases the initial approach is confidential and may not need to go further. However, where the Honours convenor feels further action is warranted the Honours convenor may approach the supervisor and/or student, or seek guidance from the Year 4 Medicine Committee and/or UNSW bodies. All concerns will be dealt with in accordance with the UNSW policy on grievance resolution procedure for undergraduate and postgraduate (coursework) students.

FEEDBACK

Supervisor(s) will complete a marking rubric with comments that will be provided to the students in Term 3. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"688ab3fcdbabac10fe4b322af49619b7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"288ab3fcdbabac10fe4b322af49619b9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Literature Review ","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

DESCRIPTION

The Literature Review is 3,000 words (+/- 10%) and as the name implies, should give a detailed account of published scientific investigations which are relevant to the project being undertaken. It should contain the following sections: 1) Introduction, 2) Hypothesis and Aims or Research Questions, 3) Methodology (study design) and 4) Reference List.

The introduction should identify the limitations of the literature and/or areas of controversy and assess them critically. It should cite appropriate studies in the field and have clear and logical flow. After introducing the research area/background, the section comprising aims, hypotheses or research questions and methodology is an opportunity to clearly state the research question to be addressed and how this will be achieved. The stated aims should relate to the area(s) outlined in the introduction and the hypotheses should be clear and valid. Together sections 2 and 3 should contain a maximum of 450-500 words (i.e. approximately 15% of the Literature Review). If more detail is required for the methodology, this can be added in an Appendix).

Methodology are to be summarised clearly and concisely and be appropriate and valid for the stated aim(s). Absolutely no results are to be included in the Literature Review. The word count for the Literature Review excludes diagrams, tables, figures, in-text citation, and final reference list, which should be integrated into the appropriate sections of the text. The referencing style is Numbered in the Literature Review.

FEEDBACK

An examiner(s) report will be provide to the student along with a completed marking rubric. The faculty examiner will also provide overall feedback based on common issues identified by examiner(s). If we have more than one examiner, the average of the two marks will be used to obtain an overall grade. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"688ab3fcdbabac10fe4b322af49619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"688ab3fcdbabac10fe4b322af49619b6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"688ab3fcdbabac10fe4b322af49619b7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"388af3fcdbabac10fe4b322af49619d6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Research Seminar","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

DESCRIPTION

The Final Seminar is a 6-minute presentation with 4 minutes of questions. The presentation should largely cover the results of the research project. A clear, concise and appropriate introduction should be provided which identifies the limitations of the literature and areas of controversy. Clear and valid aims and hypotheses or research questions should be stated. The results should reflect a significant body of work including sufficient controls and replicates and analysis of data using appropriate statistical tests. The specific contribution of the student to the results, should be included as a single Statement of Contribution slide. Presentation of the results should be clear and logical and should use figures, tables, etc. The significance of any important findings should be addressed, and appropriate conclusions made. The results of the study should be placed within a broader context and suggestions should be made for future experiments. The seminar should have clear and logical flow, good pace (i.e. neither hurried nor laboured) and use good visual quality slides and/or overheads. The student should demonstrate understanding of the questions raised during question time by giving appropriate answers and where appropriate based on the literature and current findings from their project.

FEEDBACK

An audience examiner(s) will provide comments and complete a marking rubric. If we have more than one examiner, the average of the examiner marks will be used to obtain an overall grade.

DESCRIPTION

The format of the Project Manuscript is to comply with the guidelines set out in the BSc (Med) Hons Project Manuscript - Instructions to Authors and should contain: 1) Title Page, 2) Abstract, 3) Statement of Contribution, 4) Acknowledgments, 5) Introduction with hypotheses and aims (or research questions), 6) Methodology, 7) Results, 8) Discussion, 9) References, 10) Reflection and 11) Appendix (if appropriate).

The minimum word count is 4000 and a maximum is 5000 words for the project manuscript (excluding the reflection). This word limit excludes the abstract, statement of contribution, acknowledgements and reference section, as well as the appendix (if present), tables, figures, boxes (for qualitative data only), figure legends, in-text citations.

The abstract should succinctly and accurately summarise the aims and outcomes of the project (maximum 250 words). The statement of contribution should clearly declare the specific components of the research that were undertaken independently by the student, and those components of the research that were done in collaboration with others, or that were performed by others. Being trained or supervised in a technique, but then generating the data independently, or being given advice or feedback from a supervisor or colleague, does not need to be described in this statement of contribution (but could be listed in acknowledgements). The acknowledgments should recognise the contributions (reagents, training, advice, feedback, support etc.) of others to the project.

The brief introduction aims, and hypothesis section should define the problem being examined and place it in the context of published work in the area without being a complete review of the literature. It should identify the limitations of the literature and areas of controversy and give clear and valid aims and hypotheses or research questions. The methodology should be appropriate and valid for the stated aims (or research questions) and be clearly described and fully referenced. The results should reflect a significant body of work including enough controls and replicates and analysis of data using appropriate statistical tests. Material needed for a complete understanding or evaluation of the work, but which does not fit well in the Project Manuscript format, should be included as supplementary data. Presentation of the results should be clear and logical and should use figures, tables, etc. The discussion should be relevant to the introduction, methodology, and results sections, logical in presentation and scientific content, show critical/creative analysis, place the findings of the study in the context of past studies.

The reflection section of the Project Manuscript needs to propose a future project based on the findings obtained during the BSc (Med) Hons year. The research proposal needs to provide a short rationale, hypotheses and aims (or research questions), a brief outline of methodology, potential outcomes and what they would mean to the body of literature with an emphasis on improving Indigenous health outcomes. A maximum of 1000 words will be required for this section.  

Please note that all work which is integral to the Project Manuscript but was not performed by the BSc (Med) Hons student (i.e. was undertaken by another member of the supervisor's and/or co-supervisor's research group) is to be clearly disclosed in the Methodology Results and/or appendix sections, where appropriate. This work may then be referred to in the Discussion and be assessed in the context of the work undertaken by the BSc (Med) Hons student.

FEEDBACK

An examiner(s) report will be provide to the student along with a completed marking rubric. The faculty examiner will also provide overall feedback based on common issues identified by examiner(s). If we have more than one examiner, the average of the two marks will be used to obtain an overall grade.

Together sections 2 and 3 should contain a maximum of 450-500 words (i.e. approximately 15% of the Literature Review). If more detail is required for the methodology, this can be added in an Appendix).

Methodology are to be summarised clearly and concisely and be appropriate and valid for the stated aim(s). Absolutely no results are to be included in the Literature Review. The word count for the Literature Review excludes diagrams, tables, figures, in-text citation, and final reference list, which should be integrated into the appropriate sections of the text. The referencing style is Numbered in the Literature Review.

FEEDBACK

An examiner(s) report will be provide to the student along with a completed marking rubric. The faculty examiner will also provide overall feedback based on common issues identified by examiner(s). If we have more than one examiner, the average of the two marks will be used to obtain an overall grade.

DESCRIPTION

The Final Seminar is a 6-minute presentation with 4 minutes of questions. The presentation should largely cover the results of the research project. A clear, concise and appropriate introduction should be provided which identifies the limitations of the literature and areas of controversy. Clear and valid aims and hypotheses or research questions should be stated. The results should reflect a significant body of work including sufficient controls and replicates and analysis of data using appropriate statistical tests. The specific contribution of the student to the results, should be included as a single Statement of Contribution slide. Presentation of the results should be clear and logical and should use figures, tables, etc. The significance of any important findings should be addressed, and appropriate conclusions made. The results of the study should be placed within a broader context and suggestions should be made for future experiments. The seminar should have clear and logical flow, good pace (i.e. neither hurried nor laboured) and use good visual quality slides and/or overheads. The student should demonstrate understanding of the questions raised during question time by giving appropriate answers and where appropriate based on the literature and current findings from their project.

FEEDBACK

An audience examiner(s) will provide comments and complete a marking rubric. If we have more than one examiner, the average of the examiner marks will be used to obtain an overall grade. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"608ab3fcdbabac10fe4b322af49619b6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"608ab3fcdbabac10fe4b322af49619b7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"688ab3fcdbabac10fe4b322af49619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"688ab3fcdbabac10fe4b322af49619b6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"688ab3fcdbabac10fe4b322af49619b7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"788af3fcdbabac10fe4b322af49619cf","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Project Manuscript and Reflection ","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

DESCRIPTION

The format of the Project Manuscript is to comply with the guidelines set out in the BSc (Med) Hons Project Manuscript - Instructions to Authors and should contain: 1) Title Page, 2) Abstract, 3) Statement of Contribution, 4) Acknowledgments, 5) Introduction with hypotheses and aims (or research questions), 6) Methodology, 7) Results, 8) Discussion, 9) References, 10) Reflection and 11) Appendix (if appropriate).

The minimum word count is 4000 and a maximum is 5000 words for the project manuscript (excluding the reflection). This word limit excludes the abstract, statement of contribution, acknowledgements and reference section, as well as the appendix (if present), tables, figures, boxes (for qualitative data only), figure legends, in-text citations.

The abstract should succinctly and accurately summarise the aims and outcomes of the project (maximum 250 words). The statement of contribution should clearly declare the specific components of the research that were undertaken independently by the student, and those components of the research that were done in collaboration with others, or that were performed by others. Being trained or supervised in a technique, but then generating the data independently, or being given advice or feedback from a supervisor or colleague, does not need to be described in this statement of contribution (but could be listed in acknowledgements). The acknowledgments should recognise the contributions (reagents, training, advice, feedback, support etc.) of others to the project.

The brief introduction aims, and hypothesis section should define the problem being examined and place it in the context of published work in the area without being a complete review of the literature. It should identify the limitations of the literature and areas of controversy and give clear and valid aims and hypotheses or research questions. The methodology should be appropriate and valid for the stated aims (or research questions) and be clearly described and fully referenced. The results should reflect a significant body of work including enough controls and replicates and analysis of data using appropriate statistical tests. Material needed for a complete understanding or evaluation of the work, but which does not fit well in the Project Manuscript format, should be included as supplementary data. Presentation of the results should be clear and logical and should use figures, tables, etc. The discussion should be relevant to the introduction, methodology, and results sections, logical in presentation and scientific content, show critical/creative analysis, place the findings of the study in the context of past studies.

The reflection section of the Project Manuscript needs to propose a future project based on the findings obtained during the BSc (Med) Hons year. The research proposal needs to provide a short rationale, hypotheses and aims (or research questions), a brief outline of methodology, potential outcomes and what they would mean to the body of literature with an emphasis on improving Indigenous health outcomes. A maximum of 1000 words will be required for this section.  

Please note that all work which is integral to the Project Manuscript but was not performed by the BSc (Med) Hons student (i.e. was undertaken by another member of the supervisor's and/or co-supervisor's research group) is to be clearly disclosed in the Methodology Results and/or appendix sections, where appropriate. This work may then be referred to in the Discussion and be assessed in the context of the work undertaken by the BSc (Med) Hons student.

FEEDBACK

An examiner(s) report will be provide to the student along with a completed marking rubric. The faculty examiner will also provide overall feedback based on common issues identified by examiner(s). If we have more than one examiner, the average of the two marks will be used to obtain an overall grade.

contentlets.description:
Note: MDCN8888 (8UoC) is a course selected in either Term 1 or 2 run concurrently with your chosen advanced course. 

The learning and teaching philosophy underpinning this course is centred on BSc (Med) Hons students taking on the role of researcher. In doing so, they develop advanced disciplinary knowledge, the use of specialised techniques/methodology relevant to their chosen research area, critical thinking, evaluation and synthesis of information, in addition to scientific research communication in the oral and written forms.

The principal form of teaching is based on research supervision and direction by specialist researchers within UNSW Medicine. Complementary to this, online Research Skills modules will be delivered and have been designed to provide training to BSc (Med) Hons students in diverse areas that constitute research practice. Learning outcomes from this course will form the basis for future pursuits in medical research and transferrable skills.

The information for this course is in the form of experimental techniques, protocols, technical tips and materials, which are usually provided by each laboratory and supervisor. In addition, self-directed use of other resources such as web-based sources are expected. You will need to maintain consistent communication with your supervisor and actively seek assistance from your supervisor or co-supervisor to clarify your understanding, as required.

It should identify the limitations of the literature and areas of controversy and give clear and valid aims and hypotheses or research questions. The methodology should be appropriate and valid for the stated aims (or research questions) and be clearly described and fully referenced. The results should reflect a significant body of work including enough controls and replicates and analysis of data using appropriate statistical tests. Material needed for a complete understanding or evaluation of the work, but which does not fit well in the Project Manuscript format, should be included as supplementary data. Presentation of the results should be clear and logical and should use figures, tables, etc. The discussion should be relevant to the introduction, methodology, and results sections, logical in presentation and scientific content, show critical/creative analysis, place the findings of the study in the context of past studies.

The reflection section of the Project Manuscript needs to propose a future project based on the findings obtained during the BSc (Med) Hons year. The research proposal needs to provide a short rationale, hypotheses and aims (or research questions), a brief outline of methodology, potential outcomes and what they would mean to the body of literature with an emphasis on improving Indigenous health outcomes. A maximum of 1000 words will be required for this section.  

Please note that all work which is integral to the Project Manuscript but was not performed by the BSc (Med) Hons student (i.e. was undertaken by another member of the supervisor's and/or co-supervisor's research group) is to be clearly disclosed in the Methodology Results and/or appendix sections, where appropriate. This work may then be referred to in the Discussion and be assessed in the context of the work undertaken by the BSc (Med) Hons student.

FEEDBACK

An examiner(s) report will be provide to the student along with a completed marking rubric. The faculty examiner will also provide overall feedback based on common issues identified by examiner(s). If we have more than one examiner, the average of the two marks will be used to obtain an overall grade.

DESCRIPTION

Supervisor(s) will grade the student’s performance during Honours (Term 3) by awarding a mark based on a rubric. This mark will contribute 10% of the student’s overall Honours mark. In addition to awarding a mark, supervisors are expected to make comments and provide feedback to the student about their progress during this performance review.

Supervisors may comment on such topics as the student’s participation in the collegial activities of the Research Group/Department/School (if appropriate), attendance, and the ability to meet deadlines. Space will be provided for the supervisor to add comments, or flag concerns relating to the student’s progress. These comments will be released to students.

Both students and supervisors are encouraged to discuss all concerns as they arise. Where concerns arise that cannot be resolved between the student and supervisor, or where either party wishes additional advice, both parties are encouraged to contact the ILP coordinator as soon as possible.

In all cases the initial approach is confidential and may not need to go further. However, where the Honours convenor feels further action is warranted the Honours convenor may approach the supervisor and/or student, or seek guidance from the Year 4 Medicine Committee and/or UNSW bodies. All concerns will be dealt with in accordance with the UNSW policy on grievance resolution procedure for undergraduate and postgraduate (coursework) students.

FEEDBACK

Supervisor(s) will complete a marking rubric with comments that will be provided to the students in Term 3.

DESCRIPTION

The Literature Review is 3,000 words (+/- 10%) and as the name implies, should give a detailed account of published scientific investigations which are relevant to the project being undertaken. It should contain the following sections: 1) Introduction, 2) Hypothesis and Aims or Research Questions, 3) Methodology (study design) and 4) Reference List.

The introduction should identify the limitations of the literature and/or areas of controversy and assess them critically. It should cite appropriate studies in the field and have clear and logical flow. After introducing the research area/background, the section comprising aims, hypotheses or research questions and methodology is an opportunity to clearly state the research question to be addressed and how this will be achieved. The stated aims should relate to the area(s) outlined in the introduction and the hypotheses should be clear and valid. Together sections 2 and 3 should contain a maximum of 450-500 words (i.e. approximately 15% of the Literature Review). If more detail is required for the methodology, this can be added in an Appendix).

Methodology are to be summarised clearly and concisely and be appropriate and valid for the stated aim(s). Absolutely no results are to be included in the Literature Review. The word count for the Literature Review excludes diagrams, tables, figures, in-text citation, and final reference list, which should be integrated into the appropriate sections of the text. The referencing style is Numbered in the Literature Review.

FEEDBACK

An examiner(s) report will be provide to the student along with a completed marking rubric. The faculty examiner will also provide overall feedback based on common issues identified by examiner(s). If we have more than one examiner, the average of the two marks will be used to obtain an overall grade.

DESCRIPTION

The Final Seminar is a 6-minute presentation with 4 minutes of questions. The presentation should largely cover the results of the research project. A clear, concise and appropriate introduction should be provided which identifies the limitations of the literature and areas of controversy. Clear and valid aims and hypotheses or research questions should be stated. The results should reflect a significant body of work including sufficient controls and replicates and analysis of data using appropriate statistical tests. The specific contribution of the student to the results, should be included as a single Statement of Contribution slide. Presentation of the results should be clear and logical and should use figures, tables, etc. The significance of any important findings should be addressed, and appropriate conclusions made. The results of the study should be placed within a broader context and suggestions should be made for future experiments. The seminar should have clear and logical flow, good pace (i.e. neither hurried nor laboured) and use good visual quality slides and/or overheads. The student should demonstrate understanding of the questions raised during question time by giving appropriate answers and where appropriate based on the literature and current findings from their project.

FEEDBACK

An audience examiner(s) will provide comments and complete a marking rubric. If we have more than one examiner, the average of the examiner marks will be used to obtain an overall grade.

DESCRIPTION

The format of the Project Manuscript is to comply with the guidelines set out in the BSc (Med) Hons Project Manuscript - Instructions to Authors and should contain: 1) Title Page, 2) Abstract, 3) Statement of Contribution, 4) Acknowledgments, 5) Introduction with hypotheses and aims (or research questions), 6) Methodology, 7) Results, 8) Discussion, 9) References, 10) Reflection and 11) Appendix (if appropriate).

The minimum word count is 4000 and a maximum is 5000 words for the project manuscript (excluding the reflection). This word limit excludes the abstract, statement of contribution, acknowledgements and reference section, as well as the appendix (if present), tables, figures, boxes (for qualitative data only), figure legends, in-text citations.

The abstract should succinctly and accurately summarise the aims and outcomes of the project (maximum 250 words). The statement of contribution should clearly declare the specific components of the research that were undertaken independently by the student, and those components of the research that were done in collaboration with others, or that were performed by others. Being trained or supervised in a technique, but then generating the data independently, or being given advice or feedback from a supervisor or colleague, does not need to be described in this statement of contribution (but could be listed in acknowledgements). The acknowledgments should recognise the contributions (reagents, training, advice, feedback, support etc.) of others to the project.

The brief introduction aims, and hypothesis section should define the problem being examined and place it in the context of published work in the area without being a complete review of the literature. It should identify the limitations of the literature and areas of controversy and give clear and valid aims and hypotheses or research questions. The methodology should be appropriate and valid for the stated aims (or research questions) and be clearly described and fully referenced. The results should reflect a significant body of work including enough controls and replicates and analysis of data using appropriate statistical tests. Material needed for a complete understanding or evaluation of the work, but which does not fit well in the Project Manuscript format, should be included as supplementary data. Presentation of the results should be clear and logical and should use figures, tables, etc. The discussion should be relevant to the introduction, methodology, and results sections, logical in presentation and scientific content, show critical/creative analysis, place the findings of the study in the context of past studies.

The reflection section of the Project Manuscript needs to propose a future project based on the findings obtained during the BSc (Med) Hons year. The research proposal needs to provide a short rationale, hypotheses and aims (or research questions), a brief outline of methodology, potential outcomes and what they would mean to the body of literature with an emphasis on improving Indigenous health outcomes. A maximum of 1000 words will be required for this section.  

Please note that all work which is integral to the Project Manuscript but was not performed by the BSc (Med) Hons student (i.e. was undertaken by another member of the supervisor's and/or co-supervisor's research group) is to be clearly disclosed in the Methodology Results and/or appendix sections, where appropriate. This work may then be referred to in the Discussion and be assessed in the context of the work undertaken by the BSc (Med) Hons student.

FEEDBACK

An examiner(s) report will be provide to the student along with a completed marking rubric. The faculty examiner will also provide overall feedback based on common issues identified by examiner(s). If we have more than one examiner, the average of the two marks will be used to obtain an overall grade.

contentlets.description:
Note: MDCN8889 (14UoC) is a course selected in either Term 1 or 2 and in Term 3 of the Research Intensive Honours program. 

The learning and teaching philosophy underpinning this course is centred on BSc (Med) Hons students taking on the role of researcher. In doing so, they develop advanced disciplinary knowledge, the use of specialised techniques/methodology relevant to their chosen research area, critical thinking, evaluation and synthesis of information, in addition to scientific research communication in the oral and written forms.

The principal form of teaching is based on research supervision and direction by specialist researchers within UNSW Medicine. Complementary to this, online Research Skills modules will be delivered and have been designed to provide training to BSc (Med) Hons students in diverse areas that constitute research practice. Learning outcomes from this course will form the basis for future pursuits in medical research and transferrable skills.

The information for this course is in the form of experimental techniques, protocols, technical tips and materials, which are usually provided by each laboratory and supervisor. In addition, self-directed use of other resources such as web-based sources are expected. You will need to maintain consistent communication with your supervisor and actively seek assistance from your supervisor or co-supervisor to clarify your understanding, as required.

HDR Essentials is designed to support the development of research and professional skills for commencing (1st year) Higher Degree Research (HDR) candidates to ensure that all HDR candidates in the Faculty are adequately equipped to successfully pass confirmation, and to positively affect their candidature experience and candidature outcome.


This course is compulsory for all newly enrolled HDR candidates in the Faculty of Medicine and Health. Successful completion of HDR Essentials constitutes a requirement for PhD confirmation, with PhD candidates still required to satisfy all other conditions set for the confirmation of their candidature.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"21c9ea03db6abc90595850d8f49619ab","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"ePortfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"100","description":"

This course will be assessed through the completion of a ePortfolio that will be marked as pass or fail.

The ePortfolio will be divided in 7 smaller tasks that will be completed separately after the completion of each corresponding workshop. Specifically: (1) a report describing the statistical plan that will be used to support the research project during the HDR candidature will need to be submitted as a Stat Central report. This report will also support the discussion of the methodologies and frameworks used in Medicine and Health and their application the candidate research project. (2) A UNSW Library report will be produced to capture the key point of the discussion during a consultation with the librarian and will be used to support the development of the literature review included in the thesis to demonstrate writing skills. This report will also support the discussion of the methodologies and frameworks used in Medicine and Health and their application the candidate research project. (3) The Academic Language and Learning Report will summarise the structure of the thesis that will be completed during the candidature, including the background, gap and deliverables for the project and will support the creation of research proposal to demonstrate writing skills. (4) The Career Development report will establish three objectives using the SMART goal structure that will support the HDR candidate's progress in their career planning journey. This report will demonstrate an understanding of the requirements for the successful completion of the HDR candidature and the skills that candidates will need to develop. (5) The Managing your relation with supervisor report will establish the role and expectations of HDR candidates and their supervisors for the management of the HDR candidature. This report will support a discussion regarding the research framework at UNSW and the Faculty of Medicine and Health and its application to the candidates' project. (6) The Research Progress Review report will establish the key milestones and tasks that will need to be completed to achieve a satisfactory first Research Progress Review or Confirmation Review. This report will demonstrate an understanding of the requirements for the successful completion of the HDR candidature and the skills that candidates will need to develop. (7) The Time management report will describe the organisation of a particular week during the first term of the HDR candidature and will include a reflective section on how successfully the completion of the various tasks set for that week was achieved. This report will also support the discussion of the methodologies and frameworks used in Medicine and Health and their application the candidate research project.

These report will need to be submitted within the 1st 2 terms of enrolment (full time equivalent). All 7 reports that will form the ePortfolio will be uploaded and stored on Moodle using Turnitin links.

Formative feedback will be provided by the candidates' supervisor or the workshop facilitators through meetings and/or consultations where applicable. Completion of the tasks will be monitored by the enrolling Schools/Institutes and Faculty at the confirmation review.

contentlets.description:
HDR Essentials is designed to support the development of research and professional skills for commencing (1st year) Higher Degree Research (HDR) candidates to ensure that all HDR candidates in the Faculty are adequately equipped to successfully pass confirmation, and to positively affect their candidature experience and candidature outcome.

This course is compulsory for all newly enrolled HDR candidates in the Faculty of Medicine and Health. Successful completion of HDR Essentials constitutes a requirement for PhD confirmation, with PhD candidates still required to satisfy all other conditions set for the confirmation of their candidature.
